### 1. Facts given in the task
• The task lists six logical equivalences:  
 – ¬(A ∧ B) ↔ (¬A ∨ ¬B)  
 – ¬(A ∨ B) ↔ (¬A ∧ ¬B)  
 – (A → B) ↔ (¬B → ¬A)  
 – (A → B) ↔ (¬A ∨ B)  
 – (¬A → B) ↔ (A ∨ ¬B)  
 – ¬(A → B) ↔ (A ∧ ¬B)

• It is stated that there exists one equivalence from the list that is not logically equivalent to the rest.

• The task instructs that only one correct answer exists and emphasizes the importance of certainty and verification.

### 2. Facts to look up
• Standard logical equivalences and laws, such as:
 – De Morgan's Laws: (lookup in any standard logic textbook or reliable online source such as “Wikipedia: De Morgan's laws”)
 – Material Implication: (A → B) is equivalent to (¬A ∨ B); (lookup in sources on propositional logic)
 – Contrapositive: (A → B) is equivalent to (¬B → ¬A); (standard fact available in logic materials)
 – Negation of Implication: ¬(A → B) is equivalent to (A ∧ ¬B); (verify in propositional logic texts)
• Reference information on the transformation of conditionals with a negated antecedent, to assess whether (¬A → B) is indeed equivalent to (A ∨ ¬B). (Could check sites like Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy or classical logic resources).

### 3. Facts to derive
• Derive and verify each equivalence:  
 – Confirm that ¬(A ∧ B) ↔ (¬A ∨ ¬B) and ¬(A ∨ B) ↔ (¬A ∧ ¬B) hold by De Morgan's laws.  
 – Confirm that (A → B) ↔ (¬B → ¬A) holds by the contrapositive equivalence.  
 – Confirm that (A → B) ↔ (¬A ∨ B) is equivalent by material implication.  
 – Re-derive (¬A → B) using the transformation for implications: normally, X → Y is logically equivalent to (¬X ∨ Y). Replacing X with ¬A gives (¬(¬A) ∨ B), which simplifies to (A ∨ B); then compare this with (A ∨ ¬B).  
 – Verify that ¬(A → B) ↔ (A ∧ ¬B) is correct using the negation of the material implication.
  
• Conclude that the equivalence (¬A → B) ↔ (A ∨ ¬B) is not valid when carried out – because by material implication its left side should be equivalent to (A ∨ B), not (A ∨ ¬B). This logical derivation shows that it is not equivalent to the others.

• Therefore, the specific statement that does not fit with the valid logical equivalences is:  
  (¬A → B) ↔ (A ∨ ¬B)
